member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AwaitExtensions.DownlevelRegistryWatcherSupport
member.summary: Provides a dedicated thread for requesting registry change notifications.
member.remarks: For versions of Windows prior to Windows 8, requesting registry change notifications required that the thread that made the request remain alive or else the watcher would simply signal the event and stop watching for changes. This class provides a single, dedicated thread for requesting such notifications so that they don't get canceled when a thread happens to exit. The dedicated thread is released when no one is watching the registry any more.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AwaitExtensions.DownlevelRegistryWatcherSupport.SmallThreadStackSize
member.summary: The size of the stack allocated for a thread that expects to stay within just a few methods in depth.
member.remarks: The default stack size for a thread is 1MB.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AwaitExtensions.DownlevelRegistryWatcherSupport.SyncObject
member.summary: The object to lock when accessing any fields. This is also the object that is waited on by the dedicated thread, and may be pulsed by others to wake the dedicated thread to do some work.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AwaitExtensions.DownlevelRegistryWatcherSupport.PendingWork
member.summary: A queue of actions the dedicated thread should take.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AwaitExtensions.DownlevelRegistryWatcherSupport.keepAliveCount
member.summary: The number of callers that still have an interest in the survival of the dedicated thread. The dedicated thread will exit when this value reaches 0.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AwaitExtensions.DownlevelRegistryWatcherSupport.liveThread
member.summary: The thread that should stay alive and be dequeuing .

member.summary: Executes some action on a long-lived thread.
member.param: The delegate to execute.
member.returns: A task that either faults with the exception thrown by or completes after successfully executing the delegate with a result that should be disposed when it is safe to terminate the long-lived thread.
member.remarks: This thread never posts to , so it is safe to call this method and synchronously block on its result.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AwaitExtensions.DownlevelRegistryWatcherSupport.Worker
member.summary: Executes thread-affinitized work from a queue until both the queue is empty and any lingering interest in the survival of the dedicated thread has been released.
member.remarks: This method serves as the for our dedicated thread.

member.summary: Registers to receive notification of changes to a registry key.

member.summary: Creates a TPL Task that returns true when a is signaled or returns false if a timeout occurs first.
member.param: The handle whose signal triggers the task to be completed. Do not use a here.
The timeout (in milliseconds) after which the task will return false if the handle is not signaled by that time.
A token whose cancellation will cause the returned Task to immediately complete in a canceled state.
member.returns: A Task that completes when the handle is signaled or times out, or when the caller's cancellation token is canceled. If the task completes because the handle is signaled, the task's result is true. If the task completes because the handle is not signaled prior to the timeout, the task's result is false.
member.remarks: The completion of the returned task is asynchronous with respect to the code that actually signals the wait handle.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncManualResetEvent.#ctor(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: A value indicating whether the event should be initially signaled.

A value indicating whether to allow callers' continuations to execute on the thread that calls before the call returns. callers should not hold private locks if this value is true to avoid deadlocks. When false, the task returned from may not have fully transitioned to its completed state by the time returns to its caller.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncQueue`1.completedSource
member.summary: The source of the task returned by . Lazily constructed.
member.remarks: Volatile to allow the check-lock-check pattern in to be reliable, in the event that within the lock, one thread initializes the value and assigns the field and the weak memory model allows the assignment prior to the initialization. Another thread outside the lock might observe the non-null field and start accessing the Task property before it is actually initialized. Volatile prevents CPU reordering of commands around the assignment (or read) of this field.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock
member.summary: A non-blocking lock that allows concurrent access, exclusive access, or concurrent with upgradeability to exclusive access.
member.remarks: We have to use a custom awaitable rather than simply returning Task{LockReleaser} because we have to set CallContext data in the context of the person receiving the lock, which requires that we get to execute code at the start of the continuation (whether we yield or not).
member.devnotes:
Considering this class to be a state machine, the states are:
------------- | | <-----> READERS | IDLE | <-----> UPGRADEABLE READER + READERS -----> UPGRADED WRITER --\ | NO LOCKS | ^ | | | |--- RE-ENTER CONCURRENCY PREP <--/ | | <-----> WRITER -------------

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.DgmlNamespace
member.summary: The namespace that all DGML nodes appear in.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.NoMessagePumpSynchronizationContext
member.summary: Gets a which, when applied, suppresses any message pump that may run during synchronous blocks of the calling thread.
member.remarks: The default implementation of this property is effective in builds of this assembly that target the .NET Framework. But on builds that target the portable profile, it should be overridden to provide an effective platform-specific solution.

member.summary: The object to acquire a Monitor-style lock on for all field access on this instance.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.nonConcurrentSyncContext
member.summary: The synchronization context applied to folks who hold upgradeable read and write locks.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.topAwaiter
member.summary: A CallContext-local reference to the Awaiter that is on the top of the stack (most recently acquired).

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.issuedReadLocks
member.summary: The set of read locks that are issued and active.
member.remarks: Many readers are allowed concurrently. Also, readers may re-enter read locks (recursively) each of which gets an element in this set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.issuedUpgradeableReadLocks
member.summary: The set of upgradeable read locks that are issued and active.
member.remarks: Although only one upgradeable read lock can be held at a time, this set may have more than one element because that one lock holder may enter the lock it already possesses multiple times.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.issuedWriteLocks
member.summary: The set of write locks that are issued and active.
member.remarks: Although only one write lock can be held at a time, this set may have more than one element because that one lock holder may enter the lock it already possesses multiple times. Although this lock is mutually exclusive, there *may* be elements in the set if the write lock was upgraded from a reader. Also note that some elements in this may themselves be upgradeable readers if they have the flag.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.waitingReaders
member.summary: A queue of readers waiting to obtain the concurrent read lock.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.waitingUpgradeableReaders
member.summary: A queue of upgradeable readers waiting to obtain a lock.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.waitingWriters
member.summary: A queue of writers waiting to obtain an exclusive lock.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.completionSource
member.summary: The source of the task, which transitions to completed after the method is called and all issued locks have been released.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.beforeWriteReleasedCallbacks
member.summary: The queue of callbacks to invoke when the currently held write lock is totally released.
member.remarks: If the write lock is released to an upgradeable read lock, these callbacks are fired synchronously with respect to the writer who is releasing the lock. Otherwise, the callbacks are invoked asynchronously with respect to the releasing thread.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.captureDiagnostics
member.summary: A value indicating whether extra resources should be spent to collect diagnostic information that may be useful in deadlock investigations.

member.summary: The default behavior applies.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.LockFlags.StickyWrite
member.summary: Causes an upgradeable reader to remain in an upgraded-write state once upgraded, even after the nested write lock has been released.
member.remarks: This is useful when you have a batch of possible write operations to apply, which may or may not actually apply in the end, but if any of them change anything, all of their changes should be seen atomically (within a single write lock). This approach is preferable to simply acquiring a write lock around the batch of potential changes because it doesn't defeat concurrent readers until it knows there is a change to actually make.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.LockKind.Read

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.LockKind.UpgradeableRead
member.summary: A lock that may run concurrently with standard readers, but is exclusive of any other upgradeable readers. Holders of this lock are allowed to obtain a write lock while holding this lock to guarantee continuity of state between what they read and what they write.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.HideLocks
member.summary: Prevents use or visibility of the caller's lock(s) until the returned value is disposed.
member.returns: The value to dispose to restore lock visibility.
member.remarks: This can be used by a write lock holder that is about to fork execution to avoid two threads simultaneously believing they hold the exclusive write lock. The lock should be hidden just before kicking off the work and can be restored immediately after kicking off the work.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.Complete
member.summary: Causes new top-level lock requests to be rejected and the task to transition to a completed state after any issued locks have been released.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterLock.OnBeforeWriteLockReleased(System.Func{System.Threading.Tasks.Task})
member.summary: Registers a callback to be invoked when the write lock held by the caller is about to be ultimately released (outermost write lock).
member.param: The asynchronous delegate to invoke. Access to the write lock is provided throughout the asynchronous invocation.
member.remarks: This supports some scenarios VC++ has where change event handlers need to inspect changes, or follow up with other changes to respond to earlier changes, at the conclusion of the lock. This method is safe to call from within a previously registered callback, in which case the registered callback will run when previously registered callbacks have completed execution. If the write lock is released to an upgradeable read lock, these callbacks are fired synchronously with respect to the writer who is releasing the lock. Otherwise, the callbacks are invoked asynchronously with respect to the releasing thread.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterResourceLock`2.LockFlags
member.summary: Flags that modify default lock behavior.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterResourceLock`2.LockFlags.None
member.summary: The default behavior applies.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterResourceLock`2.LockFlags.StickyWrite
member.summary: Causes an upgradeable reader to remain in an upgraded-write state once upgraded, even after the nested write lock has been released.
member.remarks: This is useful when you have a batch of possible write operations to apply, which may or may not actually apply in the end, but if any of them change anything, all of their changes should be seen atomically (within a single write lock). This approach is preferable to simply acquiring a write lock around the batch of potential changes because it doesn't defeat concurrent readers until it knows there is a change to actually make.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.AsyncReaderWriterResourceLock`2.LockFlags.SkipInitialPreparation
member.summary: Skips a step to make sure that the resource is initially prepared when retrieved using GetResourceAsync.
member.remarks: This flag is dormant for non-write locks. But if present on an upgradeable read lock, this flag will activate for a nested write lock.

member.param: A cancellation token that will revert the Join and cause the returned task to complete before the async operation has completed.
member.returns: A task that completes after the asynchronous operation completes and the join is reverted.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskCollection.joinables
member.summary: The set of joinable tasks that belong to this collection -- that is, the set of joinable tasks that are implicitly Joined when folks Join this collection. The value is the number of times the joinable was added to this collection (and not yet removed) if this collection is ref counted; otherwise the value is always 1.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskCollection.joiners
member.summary: The set of joinable tasks that have Joined this collection -- that is, the set of joinable tasks that are interested in the completion of any and all joinable tasks that belong to this collection. The value is the number of times a particular joinable task has Joined this collection.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskCollection.refCountAddedJobs
member.summary: A value indicating whether joinable tasks are only removed when completed or removed as many times as they were added.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskCollection.displayName

member.summary: An event that is set when the collection is empty. (lazily initialized)

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

true if JoinableTask instances added to the collection multiple times should remain in the collection until they are either removed the same number of times or until they are completed; false causes the first Remove call for a JoinableTask to remove it from this collection regardless how many times it had been added.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskContext.syncContextLock
member.summary: A "global" lock that allows the graph of interconnected sync context and JoinableSet instances communicate in a thread-safe way without fear of deadlocks due to each taking their own private lock and then calling others, thus leading to deadlocks from lock ordering issues.
member.remarks: Yes, global locks should be avoided wherever possible. However even MEF from the .NET Framework uses a global lock around critical composition operations because containers can be interconnected in arbitrary ways. The code in this file has a very similar problem, so we use a similar solution. Except that our lock is only as global as the JoinableTaskContext. It isn't static.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskContext.joinableOperation
member.summary: An AsyncLocal value that carries the joinable instance associated with an async operation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskContext.pendingTasks
member.summary: The set of tasks that have started but have not yet completed.
member.remarks: All access to this collection should be guarded by locking this collection.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskContext.initializingSynchronouslyMainThreadTasks
member.summary: The stack of tasks which synchronously blocks the main thread in the initial stage (before it yields and CompleteOnCurrentThread starts.)
member.remarks: Normally we expect this stack contains 0 or 1 task. When a synchronous task starts another synchronous task in the initialization stage, we might get more than 1 tasks, but it should be very rare to exceed 2 tasks. All access to this collection should be guarded by locking this collection.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskContext.IsWithinJoinableTask
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the caller is currently running within the context of a joinable task.
member.remarks: Use of this property is generally discouraged, as any operation that becomes a no-op when no ambient JoinableTask is present is very cheap. For clients that have complex algorithms that are only relevant if an ambient joinable task is present, this property may serve to skip that for performance reasons.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskContext.NoMessagePumpSynchronizationContext
member.summary: Gets a which, when applied, suppresses any message pump that may run during synchronous blocks of the calling thread.
member.remarks: The default implementation of this property is effective in builds of this assembly that target the .NET Framework. But on builds that target the portable profile, it should be overridden to provide an effective platform-specific solution.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskContext.SuppressRelevance
member.summary: Conceals any JoinableTask the caller is associated with until the returned value is disposed.
member.returns: A value to dispose of to restore visibility into the caller's associated JoinableTask, if any.

remarks.para: In some cases asynchronous work may be spun off inside a delegate supplied to Run, so that the work does not have privileges to re-enter the Main thread until the call has returned and the UI thread is idle. To prevent the asynchronous work from automatically being allowed to re-enter the Main thread, wrap the code that calls the asynchronous task in a using block with a call to this method as the expression.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskContext.HangDetails.EntryMethod
member.summary: Gets the method that served as the entrypoint for the JoinableTask that now blocks a thread.
member.remarks: The method indicated here may not be the one that is actually blocking a thread, but typically a deadlock is caused by a violation of a threading rule which is under the entrypoint's control. So usually regardless of where someone chooses the block a thread for the completion of a , a hang usually indicates a bug in the code that created it. This value may be used to assign the hangs to different buckets based on this method info.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskFactory.Run(System.Func{System.Threading.Tasks.Task})
member.summary: Runs the specified asynchronous method to completion while synchronously blocking the calling thread.
member.param: The asynchronous method to execute.

remarks.para: Any exception thrown by the delegate is rethrown in its original type to the caller of this method.

When the delegate resumes from a yielding await, the default behavior is to resume in its original context as an ordinary async method execution would. For example, if the caller was on the main thread, execution resumes after an await on the main thread; but if it started on a threadpool thread it resumes on a threadpool thread.

member.summary: Runs the specified asynchronous method to completion while synchronously blocking the calling thread.
member.typeparam: The type of value returned by the asynchronous operation.
member.param: The asynchronous method to execute.
member.returns: The result of the Task returned by .

remarks.para: Any exception thrown by the delegate is rethrown in its original type to the caller of this method.

When the delegate resumes from a yielding await, the default behavior is to resume in its original context as an ordinary async method execution would. For example, if the caller was on the main thread, execution resumes after an await on the main thread; but if it started on a threadpool thread it resumes on a threadpool thread.
See the overload documentation for an example.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskFactory.RunAsync(System.Func{System.Threading.Tasks.Task})
member.summary: Invokes an async delegate on the caller's thread, and yields back to the caller when the async method yields. The async delegate is invoked in such a way as to mitigate deadlocks in the event that the async method requires the main thread while the main thread is blocked waiting for the async method's completion.
member.param: The method that, when executed, will begin the async operation.
member.returns: An object that tracks the completion of the async operation, and allows for later synchronous blocking of the main thread for completion if necessary.

remarks.para: Exceptions thrown by the delegate are captured by the returned .

When the delegate resumes from a yielding await, the default behavior is to resume in its original context as an ordinary async method execution would. For example, if the caller was on the main thread, execution resumes after an await on the main thread; but if it started on a threadpool thread it resumes on a threadpool thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskFactory.Add(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTask)
member.summary: Adds the specified joinable task to the applicable collection.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskFactory.VerifyNoNonConcurrentSyncContext
member.summary: Throws an exception if an active AsyncReaderWriterLock upgradeable read or write lock is held by the caller.
member.remarks: This is important to call from the Run and Run{T} methods because if they are called from within an ARWL upgradeable read or write lock, then Run will synchronously block while inside the semaphore held by the ARWL that prevents concurrency. If the delegate within Run yields and then tries to reacquire the ARWL lock, it will be unable to re-enter the semaphore, leading to a deadlock. Instead, callers who hold UR/W locks should never call Run, or should switch to the STA thread first in order to exit the semaphore before calling the Run method.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Threading.JoinableTaskFactory.MainThreadAwaiter.cancellationRegistrationPtr
member.summary: Holds the reference to the struct, so that all the copies of will hold the same object.
member.remarks: This must be initialized to either null or an object holding no value. If this starts as an object object holding no value, then it means we are interested in the cancellation, and its state would be changed following one of these 2 patterns determined by the execution order. 1. if finishes before is being executed on main thread, then this will hold the real registered value after , and will dispose that value and set a default value of . 2. if is executed on main thread before registers the cancellation, then this will hold a default value of , and would not touch it.
